title: Introduction to normaliseR
text: normaliseR software package R rescaling numerical vectors feature_calculations objects produced theft R package computing time-series features. Putting calculated feature vectors equal scale crucial statistical machine learning model variables high variance can adversely impact model’s capacity fit data appropriately, learn appropriate weight values, minimise loss function. normaliseR includes function normalise (normalize) rescale either whole feature_calculations object, single vector values. following normalisation methods currently offered: z-score—"zScore" Sigmoid—"Sigmoid" Outlier-robust Sigmoid (credit Ben Fulcher creating original MATLAB version) – "RobustSigmoid" Min-max—"MinMax" Maximum absolute—"MaxAbs" normalise takes three arguments: data—either feature_calculations object containing raw feature matrix produced theft::calculate_features numeric vector containing values rescaled norm_method—character denoting rescaling/normalising method apply. Can one "zScore", "Sigmoid", "RobustSigmoid", "MinMax". Defaults "zScore" unit_int—Boolean whether rescale unit interval \([0,1]\) applying normalisation method. Defaults FALSE simple example vector: can also access individual rescaling function independently, though affords less overall control:
code: x <- rnorm(100) normed <- normalise(x, norm_method = "zScore", unit_int = FALSE) rs <- robustsigmoid_scaler(x)
